New Records: England became the first team to hold the ODI and T20 World Cups at the same time
Key Match Events: Ben Stokes hit the winning run to finish unbeaten on 51 and ensure England claimed their second T20 World Cup title
England won the toss and elected to field first, restricting Pakistan to just 8-137
Sam Curran took 3-12 from his four overs, continuing an impressive tournament for the 24-year-old Englishman
Adil Rashid finished with 2-22, including the vital wicket of Mohammad Haris with his first ball
Ben Stokes endured a nervous start with the new ball, sending down a no-ball and a wide with the first two deliveries of the game
Pre-Game Insights: Predicted rain failed to arrive and interrupt Sunday night's blockbuster decider
80,462 fans turned out for a rematch of the 1992 ODI World Cup final at the same venue
England and Pakistan both took unchanged teams into the decider after peaking at the right end of the tournament
Post-Match Reflections: Jos Buttler said he's just immensely proud of everyone in the team
Babar Azam congratulated England and said his team was just a few runs short
Ben Stokes said the bowlers, especially Adil Rashid and Sam Curran, won the game for England
Miscellaneous Highlights: Sam Curran was chosen as the player of the tournament
Ben Stokes was praised by his teammates for his clutch performance in the final
The occasion played a role in the nerves of the players, according to Chris Woakes
Others: Harry Brook said it was a phenomenal day and that England has shown the world how good they are
The first men's team to hold both the 50-over and 20-over World Cup titles at the same time
Ben Stokes was described as the ultimate competitor by Jos Buttler
